verses.text: Six days before the Passover, Jesus came to Bethany, where Lazarus was, the one Jesus had raised from the dead.
verses.comment: Bethany is significant as the home of Lazarus, whom Jesus resurrected, confirming His power over death and foreshadowing His own resurrection.

verses.text: So they gave a dinner for Him there. Martha served, and Lazarus was one of those reclining at the table with Him.
verses.comment: Martha’s service is reminiscent of her character in Luke 10:38-42, while Lazarus’s presence testifies to Jesus’s miraculous work.

verses.text: Then Mary took a pound of expensive pure nard and anointed Jesus’s feet, wiping His feet with her hair. The house was filled with the fragrance of the ointment.
verses.comment: Mary’s act is a sign of deep devotion. Anointing feet and wiping with her hair symbolizes humility and adoration, prefiguring Jesus’s burial.

verses.text: But Judas Iscariot, one of His disciples—the one who was going to betray Him—said,
verses.comment: Judas’s heart is highlighted as corrupt, giving a contrast to Mary’s love and foreshadowing his betrayal.

verses.text: “Why wasn’t this ointment sold for three hundred denarii and given to the poor?”
verses.comment: Judas seemingly appeals to care for the poor, but his motives are ulterior. This calls attention to the need for right intention in good works.

verses.text: He did not say this because he cared about the poor, but because he was a thief; he was in charge of the money bag and used to steal what was put in it.
verses.comment: Judas’s attachment to money is presented as leading to sin. The trusted role of a ‘treasurer’ also shows the ordered structure among the disciples.

verses.text: Jesus said, “Leave her alone, so that she may keep it for the day of My burial.
verses.comment: Jesus explicitly connects Mary’s act with His impending death, interpreting this loving act as preparation for His body, a theme found in sacred anointing and liturgical ritual.

verses.text: For you always have the poor with you, but you do not always have Me.”
verses.comment: Reference to Deuteronomy shows the enduring call to charity, while defending the unique moment of adoration for Jesus before His death.

verses.text: A large crowd of the Jews learned that He was there, and they came, not only because of Jesus but also to see Lazarus, whom He had raised from the dead.
verses.comment: Lazarus’s living testimony drew many, illustrating the power of public witness and the spread of faith through transformed lives.

verses.text: But the chief priests made plans to kill Lazarus also,
verses.comment: Religious authorities here are depicted as opposing not only Jesus but also the evidence of His power—a sign of hardened unbelief.

verses.text: because on account of him many of the Jews were going away and believing in Jesus.
verses.comment: The conversion of many due to Lazarus witnesses to the power of personal testimony for leading others to faith.

verses.text: The next day the large crowd that had come to the feast heard that Jesus was coming to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: This begins what is known as the Triumphal Entry, fulfilling Messianic prophecy and showing Jesus’s intentional actions in claiming His kingship.

verses.text: They took branches of palm trees and went out to meet Him, shouting, “Hosanna! Blessed is He who comes in the name of the Lord—even the King of Israel!”
verses.comment: The crowd quotes Psalm 118, a Messianic psalm. Palms were symbols of victory and kingship (cf. Rev. 7:9).

verses.text: Jesus found a young donkey and sat on it, just as it is written:
verses.comment: Fulfilling Zechariah’s prophecy, Jesus enters Jerusalem in humility—a sign of Messianic kingship marked by peace.

verses.text: “Do not be afraid, daughter Zion. Behold, your King is coming, sitting on a donkey’s colt!”
verses.comment: Direct citation of Zechariah 9:9. Riding a donkey, not a warhorse, emphasizes Jesus’s peaceful kingship.

verses.text: His disciples did not understand these things at first, but when Jesus was glorified, they remembered these things had been written about Him and had been done to Him.
verses.comment: The ‘glorification’ refers to Jesus’s death and resurrection. Full understanding comes after the resurrection, highlighting the progressive revelation of truth to the Church.

verses.text: Meanwhile, the crowd that was with Him when He called Lazarus from the tomb and raised him from the dead kept bearing witness.
verses.comment: Public testimony to Jesus’s miracles further draws others to faith. Witnessing is essential to the spread of the faith.

verses.text: This is also why the crowd met Him—because they heard He had done this sign.
verses.comment: The raising of Lazarus was a public sign; ‘signs’ in John’s Gospel are actions pointing beyond themselves to Jesus’s divine identity.

verses.text: So the Pharisees said to one another, “See, you are accomplishing nothing. Look, the whole world has gone after Him!”
verses.comment: Their words are ironic; ‘the whole world’ hints that Jesus’s mission extends beyond Israel to the entire world.

verses.text: Now among those who went up to worship at the feast were some Greeks.
verses.comment: Greeks represent Gentiles seeking God. Their presence points to the growing universality of Jesus’s mission.

verses.text: So they came to Philip, who was from Bethsaida in Galilee, and asked him, “Sir, we wish to see Jesus.”
verses.comment: The request 'to see Jesus’ expresses a deep spiritual longing that transcends ethnic boundaries.

verses.text: Philip went and told Andrew; Andrew and Philip went and told Jesus.
verses.comment: Philip and Andrew working together reflects apostolic mediation; the apostles function as channels bringing people to Christ.

verses.text: And Jesus answered them, “The hour has come for the Son of Man to be glorified.
verses.comment: ‘Son of Man’ alludes to Daniel 7. Jesus’s ‘hour’ is His Passion, death, and exaltation: glory through sacrificial suffering.

verses.text: Amen, amen, I tell you, unless a grain of wheat falls into the earth and dies, it remains alone; but if it dies, it brings forth much fruit.
verses.comment: Jesus foreshadows His death as the necessary means to produce a spiritual harvest—out of sacrifice comes abundant life for many.

verses.text: Whoever loves his life loses it, and whoever hates his life in this world will keep it for eternal life.
verses.comment: Self-denial is the path to eternal reward; a call to radical discipleship and detachment from worldly attachments.

verses.text: If anyone serves Me, he must follow Me; and where I am, there will My servant be also. If anyone serves Me, the Father will honor him.
verses.comment: Service to Jesus is directly tied to following Him, sharing in His destiny. Assurance of being with Jesus echoes hope in the heavenly reward.

verses.text: Now My soul is troubled. And what shall I say? ‘Father, save Me from this hour’? But for this reason I have come to this hour.
verses.comment: Jesus’s full humanity is apparent in His troubled soul. Yet He submits to the Father’s will—a perfect example of trust through suffering.

verses.text: Father, glorify Your Name.” Then a voice came from heaven, “I have glorified it, and I will glorify it again.”
verses.comment: The Father’s audible voice, as at other key moments, affirms Jesus’s identity. This theophany underscores Jesus’s divinity.

verses.text: The crowd standing there heard it and said that it had thundered. Others said, “An angel has spoken to Him.”
verses.comment: Divine revelation is not always perceived by all; faith prepares the way for true understanding.

verses.text: Jesus answered, “This voice has come for your sake, not for Mine.
verses.comment: Heavenly signs are for the strengthening of faith among listeners, not for Jesus’s own benefit.

verses.text: Now is the judgment of this world; now the ruler of this world will be cast out.
verses.comment: The cross will defeat the devil—the ‘ruler of this world’—and establish Christ’s kingship over all.

verses.text: And I, when I am lifted up from the earth, will draw all people to Myself.”
verses.comment: ‘Lifted up’ refers to crucifixion but also to exaltation, fulfilling Isaiah’s prophecy. Christ draws all—not some—to Himself, indicating the universality of Jesus’s redemptive work.

verses.text: He said this to show by what kind of death He was going to die.
verses.comment: The manner of death—crucifixion—follows Roman execution, prophesied by Jesus.

verses.text: The crowd answered Him, “We have heard from the Law that the Messiah remains forever. How can You say that the Son of Man must be lifted up? Who is this Son of Man?”
verses.comment: The people expected a Messiah with an everlasting earthly reign. Jesus’s statement challenges their messianic expectations, preparing them for the mystery of the cross.

verses.text: So Jesus said to them, “The light is among you for a little while longer. Walk while you have the light, lest darkness overtake you. Whoever walks in the darkness does not know where he is going.
verses.comment: Jesus is the light (John 8:12); to follow Him is to walk in truth, a major Johannine theme. Rejecting Christ leads to spiritual blindness.

verses.text: While you have the light, believe in the light, so that you may become children of light.” After Jesus had said these things, He departed and hid Himself from them.
verses.comment: Faith in Jesus makes one a 'child of light.' Jesus’s departing also anticipates the time when He would no longer be physically present, necessitating faith sustained by the Spirit.

verses.text: Even though He had done so many signs before them, they still did not believe in Him,
verses.comment: Despite miracles, many persist in unbelief—fulfilling Isaiah’s prophecy of hard-heartedness.

verses.text: so that the word spoken by the prophet Isaiah might be fulfilled: “Lord, who has believed what he heard from us, and to whom has the arm of the Lord been revealed?”
verses.comment: John explicitly connects Jewish unbelief with Isaiah 53, the Suffering Servant prophecy fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: Therefore they could not believe. For again, Isaiah said:
verses.comment: Persistent unbelief results in spiritual blindness and judgment, as prophesied in Isaiah.

verses.text: “He has blinded their eyes and hardened their heart, lest they see with their eyes, and understand with their heart, and turn, and I would heal them.”
verses.comment: The hardening is a consequence of persistent rejection of God’s revelation, as happened in Israel’s history.

verses.text: Isaiah said these things because he saw His glory and spoke of Him.
verses.comment: John affirms that Isaiah saw the pre-incarnate glory of Christ, a high christology asserting Jesus’s divinity present in the Old Testament theophanies.

verses.text: Nevertheless, many even of the authorities believed in Him, but because of the Pharisees they did not confess it, for fear of being put out of the synagogue;
verses.comment: Silence from fear of men shows the struggle for public witness. Points toward the importance of openly professing faith.

verses.text: for they loved the glory that comes from man more than the glory that comes from God.
verses.comment: Seeking human praise over God’s approval is a recurring warning. True discipleship requires embracing God’s will even in the face of opposition.

verses.text: Then Jesus cried out and said, “Whoever believes in Me, believes not in Me only, but in Him who sent Me.
verses.comment: Faith in Jesus is inseparable from faith in the Father—a strong statement on the unity between Father and Son.

verses.text: And whoever sees Me sees Him who sent Me.
verses.comment: The full revelation of the Father is found in Jesus. This theologically underscores Jesus’s divinity and divine mission.

verses.text: I have come into the world as light, so that whoever believes in Me may not remain in darkness.
verses.comment: Light is a recurring symbol for divine truth and holiness. To believe in Jesus is to come out of spiritual darkness.

verses.text: If anyone hears My words and does not keep them, I do not judge him; for I did not come to judge the world but to save the world.
verses.comment: Jesus’s mission is primarily salvation, not condemnation. Responsibility for judgment falls on rejection of His word.

verses.text: The one who rejects Me and does not receive My words has a judge; the word that I have spoken will judge him on the last day.
verses.comment: God’s revealed word is the standard of judgment. Final accountability is a central aspect of Christian teaching.

verses.text: For I have not spoken on My own authority, but the Father who sent Me has Himself given Me a commandment—what to say and what to speak.
verses.comment: Jesus’s words carry divine authority. This alludes to the Old Testament prophecy of the coming Prophet who speaks God’s words (Deut. 18:18).

verses.text: And I know that His commandment leads to eternal life. What I say, therefore, I say just as the Father has told Me.”
verses.comment: The words of Jesus bring eternal life when embraced in faith—a foundation for the authority of Jesus’s teaching and the life-giving word.
